required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this study is to assess the accuracy of a portable version of the EyeBOX device, an eye-tracking based diagnostic, in comparison to a clinical reference standard of concussion. The utility of the portable assessment to aid in the monitoring of symptoms over time after an initial diagnosis of concussion will also be evaluated.

primary_outcome.measure: Diagnostic accuracy of initial clinical diagnosis of concussion
primary_outcome.time_frame: Day 0 (when patient first presents for evaluation)
primary_outcome.description: Sensitivity and Specificity compared to the initial diagnosis of concussion

primary_outcome.measure: Diagnostic accuracy of clinical diagnosis of post-concussion symptoms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Up to one year after initial presentation
primary_outcome.description: Sensitivity and Specificity compared to post-concussion symptoms

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study participation, up to one year
primary_outcome.description: Adverse events occurring during use of the diagnostic device

secondary_outcome.measure: Diagnostic accuracy to identify increases or decreases in post-concussion symptom severity
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to one year after initial presentation
secondary_outcome.description: Correlation with increases or decreases in post-concussion symptom severity

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to one year after initial presentation
secondary_outcome.description: Subgroup analyses will be performed by age, gender, and days since incident injury

secondary_outcome.measure: Diagnostic accuracy of initial clinical diagnosis of concussion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Day 0 (when patient first presents for evaluation)
secondary_outcome.description: Positive and negative predictive value compared to initial clinical diagnosis of concussion

arm_group.arm_group_label: Patients under evaluation for Suspected Concussion

intervention.description: The portable EyeBOX takes less than 4 minutes to complete and involves watching a video move around the perimeter of an LCD monitor positioned in front of the patient while a high-speed camera continuously records gaze positions. The Portable EyeBOX software detects subtle changes in eye movements consistent with concussion and calculates a BOX score.
intervention.arm_group_label: Patients under evaluation for Suspected Concussion

study_pop.textblock: All consecutive subjects who meet all of the inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 1. Provide documented informed consent or assent along with guardian consent.
- 2. Have presented, at any time post injury, for any complaint related to an injury involving either a direct force to the head or a blow to the body that has the potential to transmit a rapid acceleration/deceleration of the head, with or without loss of consciousness, with or without external signs of head injury.
- 3. Be 5 to 67 years of age, inclusive.
- 4. Have the ability to provide a complete ophthalmologic, medical, and neurologic history as well as report current medications.
Exclusion Criteria:
- 1. Have penetrating trauma or known skull fracture or intracranial injury.
- 2. Have had a conventional head CT or MRI demonstrating evidence of structural brain injury (subdural, epidural or intraparenchymal hemorrhage, edema/mass effect per attending radiologist read).
- 3. Any of the following conditions, immediately related to the incident injury: loss of consciousness exceeding 30 minutes or best available Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score less than 13 within 24 hours or other acute conditions requiring emergency medical management.
- 4. Be blind (no light perception), have missing or non-functional eyes.
- 5. Be unable to open their eyes.
- 6. Have a history of unresolved strabismus, diplopia, amblyopia.
- 7. Have a history of unresolved cranial nerve III, IV, or VI palsy.
- 8. Have a history of unresolved macular edema, retinal degeneration, extensive cataract, or ocular globe disruption.
- 9. Have a history of extensive prior eye surgery or scarring (examples include strabismus surgery, scleral buckle repair of retinal detachment, repair of blow out fractures of the orbit and any procedures that would interfere with extraocular muscle movements; prior cataract surgery or Lasik are not exclusions).
- 10. Have a prior history of unresolved ocular-motor dysfunctions.
- 11. Be intoxicated.
